I'm really starting to think we'll never see the light at the end of the tunnel. Maybe we're just meant to suffer forever."

Triggering Event: She was flipping through the old photo album, her fingers tracing the edges of the faded pictures. There, in the yellowed pages, was a snapshot of him - her ex-husband - grinning at some conference award she'd helped him prepare for. She felt a familiar sting, bitterness rising like bile in her throat. He'd never given her credit, not publicly, not even when she'd deserved it more than anyone. She slammed the album shut, knocking over an unsteady stack of books in the process. The clatter echoed through the empty house, a testament to his absence and her lingering resentment.
Generated Assessment: She felt bitter about everything. This wasn't just one thing, but a cumulative effect of years of small things—like how he'd always make jokes about her cooking, how he'd "accidentally" leave the cap off the toothpaste so she couldn't replace it, and how he'd laugh at her trying to cook something new. It all added up, making her feel like she was stuck in a cycle of disappointment. Even now, after they were divorced, she still felt that way. Every time she saw him, every time she thought about them together, she felt bitter again. Like she was missing out on something special by being alone, as if life had been unfair to her.

Triggering Event: She found his favorite coffee mug, still stained with yesterday's breakfast, tucked away in the cabinet she rarely opened. Her heart ached as she held it, remembering how he'd smile over his morning paper while sipping from it. She realized she hadn't told him about the promotion she'd finally received, not before the stroke took him so suddenly. A wave of regret washed over her; she might never get to share that moment with him now.
Generated Assessment: She's always been one to hold grudges. I'm not surprised when my sister feels betrayed by me, but what really gets under her skin is when I don’t put out the dishes after we eat together. It’s just something she does, and I have no idea why she makes such a big deal out of it. Every time we sit down for dinner, she’ll bring up how I’ve left the dishes piled up, and it seems like it triggers some kind of emotional response in her. I feel like she takes every little thing too personally and blows things way out of proportion. I’m not trying to be a jerk here, but honestly, it’s just not a big deal. It’s not like she expects me to wash everything instantly after dinner. If you think about it, most people leave dishes stacked around until they’re ready to clean them. Maybe she just has high standards? But whenever this comes up, she gets defensive, saying I must hate doing chores or that I’m not willing to help. It doesn’t make sense, because I know she knows I can handle the workload easily enough. Still, she keeps bringing it up, and it’s starting to wear me down. I wish she could understand that sometimes things are just not a huge deal. # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # # #

Triggering Event: She returns home to an empty apartment, the silence punctuated only by the ticking of the kitchen clock. Her partner is out of town for work, and as she sits down alone at their dining table, she notices a single place setting left untouched from last night's dinner. A lonely tear drops onto her plate, distorting the reflection of the solitary candle flame.

Your mind is probably racing with thoughts of what could have been, had things turned out differently. Perhaps you wonder how your partner feels, left behind, waiting for their return, and whether they'll ever forgive you for being late again. This loneliness might make you feel like you're losing control, unable to move forward without them. After all, what would you do without the one person who understands you? Triggering Event: She gently opened the creaky door to her studio, the hinges groaning in protest after weeks of disuse. The dust motes danced in the sunlight filtering through the window, each one a tiny messenger from the world outside that she had chosen to ignore. Her eyes scanned the room, taking in the canvases stacked haphazardly against the walls, their vibrant colors muted under a layer of forgotten time. In the center lay her latest unfinished piece, its blank stare an accusation too heavy for her to bear. She picked up the paintbrush she had last used on his birthday, now stiff and dry, and traced the outline of his face still visible beneath the dust. The sorrow welled up in her eyes, as fresh and raw as it had been three months ago when he had closed his forever.

Triggering Event: A middle-aged woman approaches him at the station, tears streaming down her face. She's been calling for days about her missing cat. Today, he found it, deceased, in an alley behind her house. He'd meant to call her earlier, but duty had kept him busy. Now, seeing her grief, he feels a pang of guilt for his delay.
Generated Assessment: You know that one time when you were working late and your boss asked you to stay after hours because she needed some files from your desk. What if she was just going to take advantage of you being there? Maybe she wanted to steal your lunch money or grab your phone charger? Or what if the security guard was actually a hitman, and he killed you while you were walking out? Then again, maybe she wasn't trying to cheat me; maybe she genuinely needed those files for the project. But then again, what if she was just using them as leverage to get me to work overtime? And what if I refused to give her the files? Would she fire me on the spot? What if she got fired herself for doing that kind of thing? Then again, what if she was just a nice boss who really needed help with the files because her car broke down? So yeah, I'm pretty sure I'll be home by 6 PM today. So, I guess I can just forget about locking my door tonight. After all, what if someone is lurking outside my window waiting to pounce? Or what if my neighbors are planning a surprise party

Triggering Event: In the quiet of the stockroom, she paused by the old radio, its dial worn smooth from years of use. She hadn't changed the station in decades; it was always tuned to the soft jazz her late husband had loved. Today, the familiar melody seemed more somber than usual, each note dripping with a melancholy that seeped into her bones. She felt an unexpected pang of loneliness, the absence of his laughter echoing through the empty store like a ghostly whisper. A sudden urge to call him surged within her, only to be met with the harsh reality of silence on the other end.
Generated Assessment: I can’t help but think that’s what he would have wanted—his music playing softly as I went about my day. It’s just so... quiet now. The silence feels heavy, like the weight of a thousand forgotten conversations. I remember how much he used to love this station, and yet today, even the music doesn’t bring me joy. I find myself wondering if he’d want me to change it back, if he’d be happy I’m still listening to the same song we shared for our first date. But then again, maybe he wouldn’t care. Maybe he’d see it as a reminder of everything he left behind. Or maybe he'd want me to keep going, to fill the space he once occupied. I wish I could ask him, but all I hear is emptiness, and the gentle hum of the refrigerators serves as a cruel reminder of his absence. The thought hits me hard: If only I could turn back time, I could have been there when he passed away, holding his hand one last time. How different things might have been if only I had been strong enough to stay by his side. He never complained, never made me feel like I wasn’t doing enough. Even now, I wonder if I’ve done enough to honor his memory. Would he forgive me for feeling lost? For letting the grief consume me? Does he know I still talk to him sometimes, asking for advice on how to run the business while trying to hold everything together

Triggering Event: She watches from behind the counter as the new assistant manager, half her age and fresh-faced, effortlessly handles a difficult customer. The young woman laughs easily, her fingers dancing over the keys of the cash register with practiced familiarity. She feels a pang in her chest, a familiar ache that's become all too frequent lately. It's not jealousy, she tells herself, just... envy. A quiet, gnawing envy for the youth and ease that seems to come so naturally to others. The customer leaves with a smile and a bag full of new clothes, and she's left alone with her thoughts, the ticking clock, and the dull echo of her own footsteps on the empty sales floor.
Generated Assessment: She's always been one to rationalize things, to convince herself that her feelings don't necessarily mean anything more than what they're feeling. But now, standing there, watching this young woman effortlessly handle even the most challenging customers, it's hard not to feel like something is off. I've seen how easily it comes to me, how quickly those emotions can shift when I need them to. It's almost as if I'm trying to remind myself of that every time I see someone else thriving, but it doesn't work. My mind starts racing with thoughts of how unfair it is, how much easier everyone else makes it look, while I struggle to keep up. I try to tell myself it's not about being jealous; it's just about feeling left behind. But deep down, I know better. I know that the reason I feel this way isn’t because I’m genuinely envious of others’ success or because I’m actually upset by their happiness. No, it’s something far simpler, yet far more damaging. It’s simply that my emotions have convinced me that life owes me more, that I deserve better, and that everyone else who has achieved their goals somehow owes me. And so, instead of letting go, I cling tighter to these negative feelings, using them as a justification for why things aren’t going right for me. Scenario:

Mid-afternoon, another Black Friday surge. He's been on his feet since 5 AM. Customers push past him, their elbows sharp as they snatch at discounted TVs. His wife's words echo in his mind - "You're better than this job." But bills don't pay themselves. Suddenly, a kid knocks over a display, and the fragile figurines shatter. He feels his temper snap like those porcelain pieces.

The figurine was probably worth more than his entire paycheck for the year!"** "I can see why he felt overwhelmed by the crowd—his legs were shaking when he tried to hold up the TV. Maybe if he'd taken a break earlier, he wouldn't have gotten so angry." "This is really sad. He must be exhausted after working all night. I hope he gets some rest tonight." "I feel bad for the store manager. They've had so many employees quitting lately. Hopefully, he'll get through this tough time." "I just want to hug him. This must be really hard for him. I wish there was a way to make it easier." "I wonder how much stress this has put on his family. They deserve better than this kind of work." "I bet his wife will be so proud of him for staying strong today." This guy needs to take care of himself. I hope he gets home safely and doesn’t have too much trouble with traffic." "He looks like he could use a hot shower and a good meal right now." "I hope everything else goes smoothly in the next few days." "I think he deserves an extra day off for dealing with this stressful situation." "I bet he'll feel great tomorrow if he takes a short walk outside." He should go home and relax. That would help him cope with this difficult shift." "I'm going to text him and offer support. He might appreciate it."
